questions.text: Gestational hypertension is defined as:
questions.solution:
Gestational hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 after 20 weeks of gestation.

Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as BP of >140/90 mmHg measured 2 times with at least a 4-hour interval.

 

Gestational hypertension

Pre-eclampsia

Chronic hypertension in pregnancy

Rise in BP

After 20 weeks of pregnancy

After 20 weeks of pregnancy

Before 20 weeks of gestation

Proteinuria

Absent

May be present:

  • >300 mg in 24 hrs urine 
  • >30 mg/dl in a random urine sample
  • Urine dipstick 2+

Absent
Fall in BP to normal levels

Within 12 weeks of delivery

Within 12 weeks of delivery

Does not return to normal 

Proteinuria is not an essential criterion to define pre-eclampsia.

Pre-eclampsia is hypertension with any of the following features:

  • Proteinuria
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Liver involvement
  • Cerebral symptoms
  • Pulmonary edema.

Note: A normotensive pregnant woman may have an acute increase in BP from baseline levels and develop eclamptic seizures/HELLP syndrome, despite being normotensive. This condition is known as delta hypertension.

questions.text: What is the minimum cut-off for defining proteinuria in a random urine sample?
questions.solution:
The cut-off for defining proteinuria is ≥30 mg/dl (0.3 g/L) in a random urine sample.

Proteinuria in preeclampsia is also defined by:

  • ≥0.3 g protein in a 24-hour urine specimen.  
  • Random urine protein: creatinine ratio (PCR) ≥0.3 mg protein/mg creatinine 
  • Protein ≥1+ on urine dipstick

A urine dipstick is used only if the above quantitative methods are not available.

Note: Proteinuria is not an essential criterion to define pre-eclampsia.

questions.text: In a normal pregnancy, when does the remodeling of spiral arteries begin?
questions.solution:
In a normal pregnancy, the remodeling of spiral arteries begins at 12 weeks.

Remodeling of arteries includes invasion of arteries by trophoblasts that convert them from low-flow, high-resistance to high-flow, low-resistance vessels. These modified vessels are more capable of meeting the demands of the developing fetus.

Uteroplacental vessel development takes place in two stages:

The first stage occurs before 12 weeks post-fertilization. During this stage, invasion of spiral arteries up to myometrium occurs.

The second stage occurs between 12-16 weeks. It involves invasion of the endovascular trophoblasts into the intra-myometrial segments of spiral arteries. Interstitial trophoblasts surround the arteries.

Incomplete trophoblastic invasion leads to pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) where the vessels remain in a state of high resistance leading to placental ischemia and release of inflammatory mediators and vasoactive substances leading to endothelial injury. 

As the second stage of invasion occurs by 18 weeks, PIH develops after 20 weeks of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 patient at 17 weeks of gestation comes for a routine antenatal visit. Her blood pressure is 142/94 mm of Hg. A repeat blood pressure after 4 hours is measured to be 148/92 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario of hypertension in a patient with gestational age <20 weeks, the diagnosis is chronic hypertension. 

Chronic hypertension is diagnosed when the patient is a known hypertensive (or) BP > 140/90 mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation.

Gestational hypertension and preeclampsia are only diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: Which of the following does not put a patient at an increased risk for preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Smoking is not a risk factor for pre-eclampsia rather it is protective.

Although smoking during pregnancy causes various adverse pregnancy outcomes, it is associated with a reduced risk for hypertension in pregnancy.

Risk factors for pre-eclampsia are:

  • Previous history of pre-eclampsia
  • Primigravida: young or elderly
  • Family history: Hypertension, pre-eclampsia.
  • Placental abnormalities:
    • Hyperplacentosis: excessive exposure to chorionic villi (molar pregnancy, twins, diabetes)
    • Placental ischemia
  • Thrombophilias: APLA, Protein C, Protein S deficiency, Factor V laden mutation, homocysteinemia
  • Twin pregnancy
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Rh-negative pregnancy
  • New paternity - A new partner for subsequent pregnancies

questions.text: Which of the following does not occur in patients developing pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels
Maladaptive immunological tolerance to fetal antigens
Maladaptation to cardiovascular changes of normal pregnancy
Increased placental perfusion due to inflammation

questions.solution:
Placental perfusion is reduced in patients developing pre-eclampsia.

The development of pre-eclampsia may be explained by:

  • Abnormal trophoblastic invasion of uterine vessels, leading to decreased placental perfusion.
  • Maternal inflammatory response directed against foreign fetal antigens leading to immunological maladaptation.
  • Maternal maladaptation to cardiovascular and inflammatory changes of normal pregnancy.
  • Genetic factors and epigenetic influences.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of patients with an increased risk of pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: Low dose aspirin may reduce severity of disease
Calcium supplementation above RDA reduces the incidence
Treatment with magnesium lowers endothelin-1 concentrates
Megadoses of vitamin C has no proven benefit

questions.solution:
Calcium supplementation above the RDA does not reduce the incidence of pre-eclampsia. 

However, women who have a calcium-deficient state may benefit from calcium supplementation to reduce their risk of preeclampsia. 

Prophylactic measures for the prevention of pre-eclampsia include low-dose aspirin administration (50–150 mg/day). It is started after the 1st trimester, continued throughout pregnancy, and is to be stopped 7 days before labor.

Magnesium administration may be beneficial as it lowers endothelin-1 concentrates.

There is no role of a low salt diet, anti-oxidants, or vitamin C.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathogenesis of pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: Vascular sensitivity to angiotensin 2 is increased
There is an increase in sFlt -1 levels
A decrease in the level of soluble endoglin is seen

questions.solution:
In pre-eclampsia, there is an increase in the level of soluble endoglin.

Excessive amounts of antiangiogenic factors, increased sensitivity to angiotensin, and lowered angiotensinase levels worsen hypoxia at the uteroplacental interface.

Trophoblast of women who develop preeclampsia overproduces at least two antiangiogenic peptides that enter the maternal circulation. They increase months before clinical preeclampsia develops.

  • Soluble endoglin (sEng) is derived from the placenta and blocks endothelial nitric oxide-dependent vasodilatation. It also inhibits various TGFβ isoforms from binding to endothelial receptors.
  • Soluble Fms-like tyrosine kinase 1 (sFlt-1) is a variant of the Flt-1 receptor for placental growth factor (PlGF) and for VEGF. Increased maternal sFlt-1 levels inactivate and decrease circulating free PlGF and VEGF concentrations, leading to endothelial dysfunction.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal checkup. Her BP is 152/96mmHg. Urine analysis shows proteinuria of 3+. All of the following would be consistent with her probable diagnosis, except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of pre-eclampsia and low fibronectin is not a feature of pre-eclampsia.

Features associated with pre-eclampsia:

  • Fibronectin is a glycoprotein associated with vascular endothelial cell basement membrane and is elevated in women with preeclampsia.
  • Thrombocytopenia (HELLP syndrome)
  • Hemolysis (HELLP syndrome)
  • Increased hemoglobin, caused by a decrease in plasma volume.

Hemoconcentration is a hallmark of eclampsia. In preeclampsia, hemoconcentration is present but usually not marked.

questions.text: Which finding is most likely to be seen in a patient with pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
Decreased GFR is seen in pre-eclampsia.

During normal pregnancy, renal blood flow and GFR are increased. However, in pre-eclampsia, renal blood flow and GFR decrease due to increased renal afferent arteriolar resistance. The hallmark renal lesion is glomerular endotheliosis. Diminished filtration causes serum creatinine levels and plasma uric acid concentration levels to rise. The elevation is also due to enhanced tubular reabsorption.

The most common system involved in pre-eclampsia is the renal system.

Several studies have demonstrated that pre-eclampsia is associated with low urinary calcium. This is often used as a predictive test.

questions.text: Ophthalmic manifestations in patients with  preeclampsia syndrome include all, except:

choices.text: Central vision loss due to temporary scotoma
Permanent visual loss due to retinal artery occlusion
Permanent blindness due to serous retinal detachment

questions.solution:
Serous retinal detachment does not cause permanent visual loss. 

The most common visual symptom of preeclampsia is scotoma. 

Blindness can be due to occipital cortex edema, Purtscher’s retinopathy (retinal ischemia), or retinal detachment. The blindness is mostly reversible and corrects automatically after delivery. 

Retinal artery occlusion sometimes causes permanent vision loss.

questions.text: A patient, diagnosed with preeclampsia was brought to the emergency room with three episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, urinary incontinence, and altered sensorium for 3 hours. After stabilization, an MRI revealed the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Anterior circulation is most commonly involved
This lesions may be seen in most pre-eclampsia patients

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and radiological image are suggestive of posterior reversible leukoencephalopathy syndrome (PRES). This condition is usually reversible.

Endothelial dysfunction and cerebral autoregulation failure are implicated as etiologies of PRES. PRES lesions are almost universal in women with eclampsia but less frequent in pre-eclampsia.

PRES is characterized by the following:

  • Severe headaches
  • Altered sensorium
  • Seizures
  • Visual disturbances. 

Radiological findings in PRES:

  • Hyperintense T2 lesions in the subcortical and cortical regions of the parietal and occipital lobes.
  • The basal ganglia, brainstem, and cerebellum are commonly involved.
  • Posterior circulation is commonly involved, and anterior circulation involvement is seen in severe cases.

Neurological manifestations of preeclampsia include:

  • Headaches 
  • Convulsions
  • Cerebral edema
  • Blindness 
  • Cerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text:
Which of the following are indicators of severe disease in a patient with preeclampsia?
  1. Pulmonary edema
  2. Systolic BP >130 mmHg
  3. Mild headache
  4. Scotoma
  5. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, the presence of pulmonary edema, scotoma, or epigastric pain is indicative of severe pre-eclampsia. 

Criteria for diagnosing severe preeclampsia include:

Systolic BP Diastolic BP Proteinuria Signs of end-organ damage
≥160 mmHg ≥110 mmHg + +/-
≥140 mmHg ≥90 mmHg +/- +

Signs and symptoms of significant end-organ dysfunction are:

  • New-onset cerebral or visual disturbance i.e., photopsia, scotoma, altered mental status, and severe headache
  • Severe, persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, unresponsive to medication and not accounted for by an alternative diagnosis (OR) Serum transaminase concentration ≥2 times upper limit of normal.
  • Thrombocytopenia with platelets <100,000/microL.
  • Progressive renal insufficiency (serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dL)
  • Pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A patient at 32 weeks of gestation with pre-eclampsia is admitted to your ward. All of the following symptoms would warn you of impending eclampsia, except:
questions.solution:
Decreased deep tendon reflex is not a symptom of impending eclampsia. There will be increased deep tendon reflex i.e., hyperreflexia.

Symptoms and signs of impending eclampsia include:

  • Severe occipital or frontal headache
  • Oliguria - diminished urine output <400 ml/day
  • Epigastric pain
  • Visual symptoms - blurring, scotomas, blindness
  • Disturbed sleep
  • Ankle clonus
  • Severe elevation in blood pressure
  • Pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A G2P1 woman with a history of pre-eclampsia presents at 24 weeks of gestation for an antenatal check-up. You decide to evaluate her risk of developing pre-eclampsia in the present pregnancy. Which of the following results is not an indicator?

choices.text: Absence of diastolic notch on Doppler
High resistance index in uterine artery Doppler in the second trimester
Presence of free fetal DNA in maternal serum

questions.solution:
In this above scenario, the absence of a diastolic notch at 24 weeks on Doppler is not a predictor of pre-eclampsia.

In normal pregnant women, a diastolic notch in the uterine artery disappears by 24 weeks. Thus, a persistent diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks is predictive of preeclampsia.

 Predictors of preeclampsia:

  • Free fetal DNA in maternal plasma
  • Diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks (high resistance index in the second trimester)
  • Average MAP >90 mmHg

Predictors no longer used include:

  • Hemoconcentration
  • Elevated fibronectin
  • Increase in uric acid levels
  • Hypocalciuria - calcium in urine <12mg/dl in 24 h
  • Increased homocysteine levels
  • Roll-over test - screening test is done between 28-32 weeks.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 at 34 weeks of gestation was admitted as her BP was 150/90mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. Which of the following drugs is not suitable to control BP in this patient?
questions.solution:
Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

High BP and proteinuria are diagnostic of preeclampsia. The following drugs are used for the management of pre-eclampsia.

Drug Dose
Labetalol

100 mg TID or QID

Methyl-dopa

250–500 mg TID or QID

Nifedipine

10–20 mg BD

Hydralazine

10–25 mg BD

ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. When given in the second and third trimesters, they can cause severe fetal malformations such as:

  • Bony malformations
  • Persistent PDA
  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Limb contracture
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia.

Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy include:

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers 
  • Diuretics (contraindicated as anti-hypertensive but can be given in CCF)
  • Reserpine
  • Sodium nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension)
  • Diazoxide.

questions.text: Which is the drug of choice for controlling BP in a patient with severe pre-eclampsia?
questions.solution:
Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling BP in severe pre-eclampsia.

It is the first-line agent for urgent control of BP in pregnancy. It is effective, has a rapid onset of action, and has a good safety profile.

Labetalol is a nonselective β blocker and vascular α blocker. It should be avoided in patients with asthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction.

Choice of anti-hypertensives in pregnancy
PIH /pre-eclampsia / severe pre-eclampsia Labetalol
Acute hypertension/ Hypertensive crisis IV labetalol, nifedipine, hydralazine
Chronic hypertension in pregnancy Labetalol > methyl dopa.

Option B: Hydralazine causes maternal hypotension and fetal distress.

Option C: Nifedipine causes reflex tachycardia and headache in the mother.

Option D: In methyldopa, a change in BP is an indirect action. So it is less effective in controlling BP.

Note: Experimental antihypertensive drugs for pre-eclampsia treatment are calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and anti-digoxin antibody Fab (DIF). DIF is directed against endogenous digitalis-like factors, also called cardiotonic steroids.

questions.text: A G3P1A1, preeclamptic patient at 33 weeks of gestation came for a regular antenatal check-up.  At present, her BP is 130/90 and an NST is reactive. What is the plan of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of mild pre-eclampsia as the patient has a BP of 130/90 mmHg and no fetal compromise. Hence, the plan of management would be to wait till 37 weeks for termination.

Hypertensive condition

Time of delivery

Gestational hypertension

38–39 weeks

Mild pre-eclampsia

≥37 weeks

Severe pre-eclampsia

≥34 weeks

Eclampsia, HELLP syndrome

Immediate termination irrespective of gestational age

In all cases of hypertension during pregnancy, the preferred mode of delivery is vaginal. Cesarean is indicated only for any co-existing obstetrical reasons.

questions.text: A 33-week-pregnant lady with pre-eclampsia presents with features suggestive of HELLP syndrome. Which of the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Corticosteroids aid in increasing platelet count
It is characterised by microangiopathic hemolysis
MgSO4 can be used in the management of HELLP syndrome
Termination of pregnancy is the definitive management

questions.solution:
Corticosteroid treatment for thrombocytopenia is not recommended in patients with HELLP syndrome.

HELLP syndrome is a serious complication in pregnancy characterized by HEmolysis, ELevated liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count. It occurs in 0.5-0.9% of all pregnancies and in 10–20% of patients with severe preeclampsia.  

Management of HELLP syndrome is supportive, including:
- Antiseizure prophylaxis with MgSO4
- Platelet tansfusion if platelet count <50,000/mm3 , FFP transfusion
- Plasmapheresis
- Immediate termination of pregnancy in the interest of the mother.

 The most common cause of maternal death in HELLP syndrome is abruptio placenta and DIC.

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding HELLP syndrome?

choices.text: PT,  PTT,  fibrinogen levels are normal
All patients with HELLP syndrome have abnormal BP
Tennessee criteria is used for diagnosis

questions.solution:
15% of pregnant women with HELLP syndrome have normal blood pressure.

HELLP syndrome occurs at 27-37 weeks. PT, PTT, and fibrinogen levels are normal. This differs from DIC where PT and PTT are elevated while the plasma fibrinogen level is decreased.

Tennessee criteria is used for diagnosis and Mississippi classification is used to grade HELLP syndrome.

  • Tennessee criteria for diagnosis of true/complete HELLP
    • Platelet count <1 lakh/cu mm
    • AST >70 IU/L, 
    • LDH >600 IU/L
  • Mississippi classification divides HELLP into 3 grades based on the platelet count.

questions.text: A G2P1 patient at 25 weeks of gestation is brought to the emergency with right upper quadrant pain and one episode of seizure. CBC reveals a Hb of 7.6gm/dl and a platelet count of 70,000/microL. What is the definitive management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and HELLP syndrome. The definitive management is the termination of pregnancy.

In cases of pre-eclampsia, indications for termination of pregnancy, irrespective of gestational age, are as follows:

  • Eclampsia (give MgSO4 followed by induction of labor)
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Persistent symptoms of severe pre-eclampsia or severe hypertension
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Significant renal dysfunction, coagulopathy
  • Abruption of placenta
  • Fetal compromise

In mild pre-eclampsia, steroids are given and the patient is delivered at 37 weeks.

In severe pre-eclampsia:

  • If pregnancy is >34 weeks - MgSO4 is given for prophylaxis of eclampsia and the pregnancy is terminated.
  • If pregnancy is at 27-34 weeks - in the absence of contraindications, expectant management is followed and the baby is delivered at 34 weeks, as shown below in the flowchart.

questions.text: A pre-eclamptic patient at 30 weeks of gestation is rushed to the hospital as she suddenly lost her vision 1 hour ago. During admission, she has a seizure. Which of the given statements is correct?

choices.text: Convulsions within 7 days of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia
Thrombocytosis is likely to be found
Blindness due to this condition is usually reversible

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia. Blindness due to eclampsia is usually reversible.

Blindness due to eclampsia can be due to a central or peripheral cause. It is irreversible only if the etiology is a combination of retinal infarction and bilateral lateral geniculate nuclei lesions.

Option A: Convulsions within 48 hours of delivery are called postpartum eclampsia.

Option B: The most common hematological finding in pregnancy-induced hypertension is thrombocytopenia.

Option D: The seizures are generalized seizures.

Note: The most common cause of death in patients with eclampsia is intracerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text: A G3P2 patient with preeclampsia develops seizures and is started on the Pritchard regimen. What level of serum magnesium should be maintained in this patient in order to prevent seizures?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of eclampsia and to control fits, optimum serum magnesium levels of 4-7 mEq/L have to be maintained. 

MgSO4 regimens for management of eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia:

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Intramuscular         (Pritchard)

4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 min
followed by
10 g (50%), deep IM (5 g in each buttock)

5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in alternate buttocks

Intravenous (Zuspan or   Sibai)

4g IV slow over 15–20 minutes

1–2 g/hr IV infusion

questions.text: The mechanism of action of MgSo4 includes all, except:

choices.text: It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to Ach

questions.solution:
MgSO4 blocks calcium influx, not sodium.

Mechanism of action of MgSO4:

  • It is a membrane stabilizer and acts as a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach.
  • It blocks neuronal calcium influx.
  • It reduces the presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate.
  • It blocks glutaminergic NMDA receptors and potentiates adenosine action.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication to skip the next dose in a patient with severe pre-eclampsia taking MgSO4 prophylactically?
questions.solution:
Repeat injections of MgSO4 are given only if knee jerks are present.

The next dose of MgSO4 is only given when all signs of magnesium toxicity are absent.

Signs of magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per min)
  • Urine output <30 ml/hr
  • Chest pain, heart block

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10 ml (10% solution) IV

Side effects of MgSO4:

  • Anuria
  • Pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia is started on prophylactic MgSO4 in view of signs of impending eclampsia. An hour later, examination reveals RR - 16 breaths/minute and absent patellar reflexes. What is her plasma concentration of MgSO4 most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Patellar reflexes disappear when plasma magnesium concentration reaches 10 mEq/L. As there is no respiratory depression, the plasma concentration is likely to be 10-12 mEq/L.

The disappearance of the patellar reflex is the first sign of impending magnesium toxicity. MgSO4 is prophylactically used in impending eclampsia, severe pre-eclampsia, and HELLP syndrome.

Signs of magnesium toxicity Plasma concentrations of magnesium (mEq/L)
Loss of patellar reflex 10–12
Respiratory depression 12-13 
Cardiac arrest >30

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in:

choices.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.solution:
Magnesium sulfate has no role in the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in a premature baby, where there is a deficit of surfactant (which results in alveolar collapse).

Magnesium in the MgSO4 competes with calcium on voltage-gated calcium channels, thereby altering its uptake and release. Functions of MgSO4 include :

  • Membrane protector and neuro stabilizer. It is used in the prevention of cerebral palsy in very low birth weight neonates.
  • Reduction of motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine, and thus is used as an adjunct in the management of acute severe asthma in children and adults
  • Blocking of neuronal calcium influx, and is thus used in the conservative management of pre-term labor (tocolytic, option D)
  • Inducing cerebral vasodilatation, dilating the uterine arteries, increasing the production of endothelial prostacyclin, and inhibiting platelet activation. Hence it is used in the management of pre-eclampsia (option A) and to prevent progression to eclampsia (option A).

questions.text: A primigravida at 33 weeks of gestation was rushed to the hospital with recurrent seizures. Her husband says that prior to the seizures, she had complained of a headache and visual disturbances. She was on antihypertensives from the first trimester and there is no history of neurological disease. Which of the following is true regarding her management?

choices.text: First step of management is intravenous MgSO4
Diazepam is recommended as an anticonvulsant if MgSO4 fails
Treatment may be based on recommendations from the Magpie trial
Maternal alkalosis commonly occurs and needs correction

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of eclampsia and management may be based on recommendations from the Magpie trial.

The Magpie trial showed that prophylactic use of magnesium sulfate lowers the risk of eclampsia.

The first step in the management of eclampsia is maintaining the airway, ensuring oxygen delivery to both mother and fetus. Then, MgSO4 is administered to control seizures.

Thiopentone > phenobarbitone may be used to control seizures. No attempt should be made to shorten the convulsion using diazepam as it often leads to thrombophlebitis and respiratory depression. 

Maternal acidosis usually occurs and is corrected when present.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding eclampsia?
  1. Antepartum onset has the worst prognosis
  2. The outcome depends on the severity of hypertension.
  3. The most common cause of death is renal failure.
  4. The most common MRI finding is subcortical white matter edema.
  5. It most commonly occurs during the intrapartum period
questions.solution:
Antepartum eclampsia has the worst prognosis and the most common MRI finding of eclampsia is subcortical white matter edema.

Antepartum eclampsia is the most common type of eclampsia. It has the highest rate of maternal mortality.

The outcome of eclampsia depends on the duration of hypertension and not severity. The most common cause of death in eclampsia and severe pre-eclampsia is intracranial bleeding.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation?
questions.solution:
Supine vena cava syndrome is the complication of the given representation. The image shows compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus which can sometimes lead to supine hypotension.

During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the great vessels against the hard spine, when the patient is in the supine position. Of the two vessels, the vena cava is compressed, but the aorta, owing to its structure is relatively resistant.

Normally, the vena cava compression results in opening up collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygous veins but in some cases, when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed resulting in hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope and is called supine vena cava syndrome.

The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to the lateral position.
